title: MethScope-MRMP
text: provided three reference MRMPs definitions, want create MRMPs definitions, please follow following tutorial. Download install YAME (https://zhou-lab.github.io/YAME/) Process methylation reference file .cg file run following yame rowop code binarize input file (default threshold 0.5, use -b adjust threshold needed) Generate reference definition (default min CG per MRMP 50, adjust threshold needed min_CG) Pack generated pattern.txt .cm file can directly used reference_pattern GenerateInput function.
code: yame rowop example.cg -o binstring > example_binstring GenerateReference(example_binstring) yame pack -f s patterns.txt patterns.cm

what: Generate MRMPs reference from cell type pseudobulks
title: MethScope-MRMP
text: might useful generate MRMPs reference cell type pseudobulks cell type label available. Obtain txt file contains sample names belong oen cell type want merge together cell type label. Generate pseudobulk profile using yame subset rowop Please check full code GenerateReference.sh analysis folder (https://github.com/zhou-lab/MethScope) reference parallel process multiple cell types. obtaining pseudobulk profile, steps obtain MRMPs definition file.
code: yame subset -l samples.txt example.cg | yame rowop -o musum - example_pseudobulk.cg

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: code, demonstrate genate cell MRMPs matrix using example.cg file. Replace .cg data file path, details create .cg file, please check (https://zhou-lab.github.io/YAME/). provided three reference MRMPs definitions (mouse brain human pan tissues), please check MRMPs reference tutorial creating reference. input data contains many cells, recommend splitting .cg files run code parallel improve runtime. split .cg files, please refer (https://zhou-lab.github.io/YAME/docs/subset.html). understanding pattern, please check knowYourCG tool: https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/knowYourCG.html
code: example_file <- system.file("extdata", "example.cg", package = "MethScope") reference_pattern <- system.file("extdata", "Liu2021_MouseBrain.cm", package = "MethScope") input_pattern <- GenerateInput(example_file, reference_pattern)

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: use pre-trained model, simply use PredictCellType function shown ultra fast cell type annotation. provided two built pre-trained models mouse brain: Liu2021_MouseBrain_P1000 human tissue atlas: Zhou2025_HumanAtlas_P1000.

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: train model, use Input_training function cell_type_label vector correspond row input_pattern matrix. can provide list xgb model parameters set cross_validation = T find optimal parameter.

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: provided built functions visualizing prediction results
code: umap_plot <- PlotUMAP(input_pattern,prediction_result) ### cell_type_label is the true cell type label PlotConfusion(prediction_result,cell_type_label) PlotF1(prediction_result,cell_type_label)

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: Cell type proportions can estimated nnls_deconv functions, obtain reference input, please check (https://github.com/zhou-lab/methscope_data) stores reference pseudo bulk .cg files.
code: reference_pattern <- system.file("extdata", "Liu2021_MouseBrain.cm", package = "MethScope") reference_input <- GenerateInput("2021_LiuMajorTypePseudo.cg",reference_pattern) reference_input <- imputeRowMean(reference_input) cell_proportion <- nnls_deconv(reference_input,input_pattern)

title: MethScope-Tutorial
text: obtaining cell MRMPs matrix input_pattern, simply use cluster cells using existing pipeline. demonstration using Seurat clustering UMAP plotting
code: Pattern.obj <- CreateSeuratObject(counts = t(input_pattern), assay = "DNAm") VariableFeatures(Pattern.obj) <- rownames(Pattern.obj[['DNAm']]) DefaultAssay(Pattern.obj) <- "DNAm" Pattern.obj <- NormalizeData(Pattern.obj, assay = "DNAm", verbose = FALSE) Pattern.obj <- ScaleData(Pattern.obj, assay = "DNAm", verbose = FALSE) ### Can directly use the initial counts matrix Pattern.obj@assays$DNAm@layers$scale.data <- as.matrix(Pattern.obj@assays$DNAm@layers$counts) Pattern.obj <- RunPCA(Pattern.obj,assay="DNAm",reduction.name = 'mpca', verbose = FALSE) Pattern.obj <- FindNeighbors(Pattern.obj, reduction = "mpca", dims = 1:30) Pattern.obj <- FindClusters(Pattern.obj, verbose = FALSE, resolution = 0.7) Pattern.obj <- RunUMAP(Pattern.obj, reduction = "mpca",  reduction.name = "meth.umap", dims = 1:30)

code: @Manual{,   title = {MethScope: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding},   author = {Hongxiang Fu},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0}, }

what: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding
title: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding
text: MethScope identifies Recurrent Methylation Patterns (MRMPs) basis encode latent representations interpretatble analysis DNA mehtylation data, particular single cell spatial methylome. MRMPs embeddings support automatic cell annotation, bulk deconvolution, unsupervisded clustering, cancer cell origin prediction.

title: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding
text: Install released version usethis CRAN: install github

title: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding
text: MethScope performs rapid cell annotation, deconvolution tasks single cell spatial DNA methylome. Please check documentation details: Explore MethScope Website

title: Ultra-fast Analysis of Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding
text: use MethScope, kindly cite (coming soon): Hongxiang Fu, Chin Nien Lee, Cameron Cloud, Hao Xu, Yanxiang Deng, Wanding Zhou, MethScope: Ultra-fast Analysis Sparse DNA Methylome via Recurrent Pattern Encoding.
